awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Role of Material Culture in Determining Social Affiliation
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation project utilizes the concept of globalization, or the process of interaction and integration among diverse people, to investigate the spread and adoption of customs over space and time. While it is tempting to draw broad comparisons between many groups that share commonalities in practices, belief systems, and material culture, globalization can potentially transform groups into blended communities with complex identities. Globalization as a social process is most often used to describe the modern world, but versions of this phenomenon can be recognized throughout history. Like modern processes, premodern examples represent the spread of cultural traits on impressive scales that fostered transformative interaction and restructuring. 

This study addresses globalization by analyzing how changes in ceramic manufacturing can be indicative of how ‘global’ craft knowledge was transferred within regions and the degree at which these practices were integrated with local traditions. Beginning around AD 1000, one region experienced a period of globalization (“Mississippianization”), which affected many aspects of religious and daily life. While ongoing archaeological research of the mid-continental United States often focuses on a pattern of discrete cultural attributes spread from a central location, premodern globalization was more likely a variable process that led to differing local versions of a shared culture based in part upon each group’s political, environmental, and social settings. The project focuses on this era of critical social change, as well as the centuries preceding and following, (AD 600-1550). To understand the fusion of global and local practices, this project studies how cultural transformations unfold through daily technical potting choices at the macroscopic, microscopic, and elemental levels. This project integrates chemical data collected via laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) and mineralogical data collected via ceramic petrography and X-ray diffraction (XRD). Instead of concentrating on prestige items, this study shows that everyday objects, including very small sherds, can be used to understand the adoption and adaptation of past traditions. These compositional studies assess the array of ceramic manufacturing practices, which will inform regarding continuity, change, and amalgamation of natural resource utilization and technological choices over space and time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Beginning around A.D. 1000, the mid-continental United States experienced a period of premodern globalization. Two archaeologically-defined periods are investigated in this study, the Woodland (ca. 1200 B.C. -  A.D. 1000) and the Mississippian (ca. A.D. 1000 - 1550) periods. During the Woodland period, communities were generally semi-sedentary and primarily relied on hunting and foraging and the cultivation of a few native domesticates. Following this, around ca. A.D. 1000, Woodland societies across much of the Southeast and lower Midwest experienced a process of “Mississippianization.” This term refers to the process whereby regions incorporated the Mississippian culture and associated practices. The Mississippian period is broadly defined by centralized communities with mounds placed around plazas, intensive maize agriculture, and social stratification, as well as shared religious and iconographic systems.

This study also utilized the concept of glocalization, or the local adaptation of “global” beliefs and practices in concurrence with established traditions and values, to understand the local incarnation of the Mississippianization process among the communities of the Central Tombigbee River drainage located in Alabama and Mississippi. By focusing on craft production and domestic pottery, this project explored how people interacted with global Mississippian ideas and practices and integrated them into their daily lives based on long-standing local traditions and norms. This project utilized collections from six archaeological sites from the Central Tombigbee River drainage and curated at the Cobb Institute of Archaeology at Mississippi State University and the University of Alabama Museums. These collections were chosen from domestic contexts dating to the era of Mississippianization, as well as the centuries preceding and following (A.D. 600 - 1550). Contexts were dated using diagnostic artifacts and AMS assays. AMS dating results obtained in this study have provided a more accurate and detailed timeline of occupation in the region.

Pottery analysis for this project involved studying macroscopic attributes, chemical signatures (via laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry [LA-ICP-MS]), and mineralogical compositions (via ceramic petrography and X-ray diffraction [XRD]) of ceramic assemblages to understand the raw materials used to create the pottery and how the vessels were made over time. These results suggest that Mississippian traditions were slowly and deliberately integrated in the Tombigbee region. Manufacturing data show that new Mississippian practices were utilized in combination with older local traditions. Additionally, sourcing data indicate that many of the vessels were made outside of the study region and potentially arrived through the relocation of groups from other declining sites. Together, these data suggest that Mississippianization in the region was an ongoing process of interaction and integration that likely involved the arrival of immigrants who introduced Mississippian practices and ideas. Despite this, Central Tombigbee River drainage communities were not quickly or effectively homogenized or changed. Instead, they were active participants in the making and remaking of their own traditions, practices, and identity and created their own local version of the Mississippian culture.
